September 22 , 2020  
Telec onference ID:  457 895 802 #  
Per Governor’s Executive Order N -25-20 
 
 
1. Call to Order        
Chairperson Nila Hogan called the meeting to order at 5:3 2 p.m.     
a. Moment of Silence  
b. Reading of the Promise of Community Action  
“Community Action changes people ’s lives, embodies the spirit of  hope, improves  communities,  
and makes America a better place to live. We care about the entire community and we are 
dedicated to helping people help themselves and each other.”  
 
2. Roll Cal l/Set Quorum      
Secretary Kaylonie Howard conducted roll call; quorum was established.  
Policy Council  Members Present: Nila Hogan, Destiny Thompson Butler , Hernan Lozano, Nicole Cabe, 
Kaylonie Howard, Andrea Martinez, Isabelle Diaz, Isabel Everly, Brittany Dunbar, Bianca Garibay                    
3. Approval of Agenda         *ACTION  
a. A motion was made by Nicole Cabe  to approve the agenda dated September 22 , 2020; 
seconded by Destiny Thompson Butler .  Motion carried unanimously.  
 
4. Approval of Minutes      Chairperson   *ACTION  
a. A motion was made by Isabelle Diaz  to approve the minutes of August 25 , 2020; seconded by 
Isabel Everly .  Motion carried unanimously.  
 
5. Presentation of Guests / Public Forum  
The following guests were in attendance: Yolanda Gonzales, Director Head Start/State Child 
Development; Jerry Meade, Assistant Director of Head Start/State Child Development -
Program ; Gloria Barbero Assistant Director of Head Start and State Child Development -San 
Joaquin; Sylvia Ortega, Quality Assurance Administrator; Esperanza Contreras, Partnership 
Adminis trator ; LeTisha Brooks, Program Administrator; Janey Felsoci , Program Manager;  
Jackie Escobar, Professional Development Manager; Vanessa Cortez, Administrative Analyst; 
Nicole Nino, Family Engagement Specialist/Home Base Supervisor; Lisa Price, Program 
Gov ernance Coordinator  
a. The public wishing to address the full Policy Council may do so at this time. Policy Council 
members may respond briefly to statements made or questions posed.  However, the P olicy 
Council  will take no action other than that referring th e item(s) to staff for study and analysis . 
Speakers are limited to five minutes each . If more than one person wishes to address the 
same topic,  total group time for the topic will be 10 minutes. Please state your name before 
making your presentation. Thank y ou. 
None  
 
6. Standing Committee Reports            
a. School Readiness  Committee   
The School Readiness Committe e met virtually on September 15, 2020  to discuss health and  
nutrition.  The COVID -19 Health Protocol was shared with members along with Child Care 
Licensing immunization requirements.  The new mealtime process was reviewed , with members 
encouraged to have  family style dining at home when possible.  Additional School Readiness 
updates included the Education Team working on enrolling  children and families for a new 
online program to assist with developmental assessments.  There are also Teacher Wellness 
news letters being sent to centers with wellness meetings being offered.  Family Engagement is 
registering  parents  for Ready Rosie .  The Inclusion Team is creating goal setting and observation 
sheets for children who have an IEP/IFSP. Virtual training has been conducted by the Health  
 Team with the Nutrition team busy working on special diets at centers.  The next Policy Council 
School Readiness Meeting will be held via teleconference on October 20, 2020 at 5:30 p.m.   
b. Planning Committee   
The Planning Committee met on September 1, 2020. Sylvia Ortega presented the Head 
Start/Early Head Start Kern self -assessments reviewing all key findings with members.  Planning 
Committee members approved the self -assessments.  Enrollment information across a ll grants 
was also shared with the committee.   Child Adult Care Food Program (CACFP) information was 
also reviewed. It was noted that the agency’s compliance standards have been successfully 
sustained during this time of the COVID -19 pandemic. Reviews are and will continue to be 
conducted through monitoring, minimizing the risk of transmission to children and staff.   
c. Budget & Finance Committee   
The Budget & Finance committee met on September 15, 2020 through teleconference.  Budget 
to actual financial documents for all grants as well as Parent Activity Funds and Parent Local 
Travel and Reimbursement was also shared.  The subcommittee will meet again for its final 
meeting of the 2019 -2020 term on October 20, 2020 at 5:30 p.m. via teleconference.  
d. Bylaws Committee   
The Bylaws Committee met via teleconference on September 8, 2020.  The  current draft version 
of the bylaws which included recommendations by administration  was reviewed and approved .  
It was shared that there wer e not any  significant changes made to the document.  Most notable 
was the inclusion of teleconference meetings and voting as well as additional responsibilities to 
the position of Policy Council Board of Directors Representative.   There w ere also minor 
formatting and grammatical edits  made to the document.   The Policy Council Bylaws  will be 
presented to the CAPK Board of Directors for approval at their October meeting .  The next  
Bylaws  Committee meeting is scheduled for October 8, 2020 via teleconference at 5 :30 p.m.    
 
7. Presentations           
None  
 
8. New Business                      *ACTION  
a. San Joaquin Goals & Objectives and Refunding Application ~ Jerry Meade, Assistant Director of 
Head Start & State Child Development -Program  
Jerry  Meade  reviewed the goals and objectives for the Early Head Start San Joaquin program.  
In doing so, measurable objectives, p rogress on such as well as any challenges encountered 
were shared specific to each of the four goals.  Significant strides were made in the majority of 
areas.  A challenge was noted in in Goal I , Consistency of Process/ Systems .  This was due to 
delays cr eated by the COVID -19 pandemic in electing and implementing a system to utilize the 
desired pilot program (ACORN/Tableau).  In the interim, the program will continue to develop 
policies and procedures with data driven framework.  Budget detail for the 2021 -2022  San 
Joaquin fiscal year was also provided and reviewed.  Upon conclusion of the presentation, a 
motion was made by Nicole Cabe  to approve the submission of the San Joaquin Goals & 
Objectives and Refunding Application to the Office of Head Start .  Destiny Thompson Butler 
seconded;  motion carried unanimously.

10. Program Governance Report/Train ing ~ Lisa Price                                                                                                    
Lisa Price thanked members  for taking the time out of their evening to join the meetin g, noting the 
end of this term is drawing near.  She spoke to a few items contained in the Policy Council packet.  
Lisa asked members to review the fire safety/prevention handout in the packet .  This is  especially 
important as there are currently many fires burning, some even within close proximity.  The absolute 
importanc e of having a plan in place to ensure safety for one’s family was also stated .  Information 
was also shared with regard to drive up dental services.  Lisa noted  that concern was expressed 
during the recent School Readiness subcommittee regarding the inabili ty to schedule dental visits  for 
children  in a timely manner.  It was the hope that this free drive up dental opportunity  for children 0 -
5 years of age  could be of benefit to families.  Lisa also spoke briefly with regard to voter registration, 
encouraging  members to register and/or simply check their registration status.  Census information 
was also touched  on. It was noted information regarding this topic and the importance of such has 
been shared with members over the past several months in a variety of ways.  Members were also 
encouraged to share all information presented with others. In closing , Lisa gave an update on the  
Policy Council interest survey for the 2020 -2021 term.  She stated that this survey will be sent out 
within a S’more Newsletter.  She  encouraged members who are eligible and interested in potentially 
serving another term to complete the survey.  Attendees were again thanked for their participation 
and attendance.       
 
11. Director ’s Repor t (HS/State Child Development ) ~ Yolanda Gonzales      
Yolanda thanked members for their approval of the San Joaquin action items. She added that this 
has been a very unusual year, not one we are used to .  She expressed appreciation for the 
commitment from Policy Council members.  Yolanda  shared that d uring this time , staff continue s to 
implement all health and safety protocols at centers  to help parents feel comfortable in leaving 
their children as we continue to provide high quality services.  Yolanda encouraged members to 
share their story with other parents as Lisa prepares to send out the Policy Council interest survey.  
Yolanda shared with the group that she is currently in San Joaquin sharing that it is al ways a delight  
to be there .  She reported that Gloria and her administrative team in San Joaquin continue to work 
very hard as they too follow protocol to ensure health and safety measures for COVID -19.  San 
Joaquin is  also busy renovating some of their si tes just as we are in Kern.  It was shared that we are 
very close to opening our new Angela Martinez Center (in Kern) and are very excited about that ,  
 adding  there is a lot of licensing taking place.   Yolanda once again thanked members for their 
dedication  and ongoing  support and helping to continue to provide an excellent program .  She 
also urged everyone  to continue to be safe.  In closing , Yolanda  shared that she looks forward to 
having members return next term whether it be their second or third year  she knows they will be 
happy in continuing to support the Council and our program.  
            
12. Policy Council Chairperson/Announcements  ~ Nila Hogan    
Nila Hogan  indicated  that she appreciates the staff and all that they do , adding she knows parents 
are really appreciative and that she likes to take this time to reiterate that.  Nila also expressed 
appreciation to  Policy Council members noting  that most everyone has been showing up, even 
though it’s been tough.  Nila again expressed gratitude that members were able to attend this 
evening.  
 
13. Adjournment  ~ Chairperson         
Prior to adjournment closing comments were shared by members who graciously thank ed staff.

6. Reportes de comités permanentes          
a. Comité  de preparación  escolar   
El comité  de preparación  escolar se reunió virtualmente el 15 de septiembre para discutir temas 
de salud y nutrición. Se compartió el protocolo de salud con los miembros presentes , así mismo 
se revisaron los requisitos de  vacunación de la oficina de emisión de licencias para cuidado 
infantil. También  se exhortó a los presentes a continuar las cenas familiares en casa mientras les 
sea posible. Un tema destacado  fue la inscripción de los niños (as) y familias en un programa en 
línea, que los asiste con las evaluaciones de desarrollo. También  se informó  de la existencia de  
 boletines para el bienestar de los maestros, que se estaban enviando a los planteles,  así como 
invitaciones a participar en juntas de bienestar . La división de compromiso familiar  continúa  
registrando a los padres en el programa de Ready Rosie. La división de incorporación  se 
encuentra  en la  creación y desarrollo de formas de observación para los alumnos que cuentan 
con una evaluación  de IEP e IFSP. La división de salud en conjunto con la división de nutrición, 
se encuentran trabajando arduamente en el desarrollo de dietas  especiales para los planteles. 
La próxima junta del comité de preparació n escolar se llevará a cabo el 20 de octubre, 2020 a 
las 5:30 p.m.  
b. Comité  de planeación   
El comité  de planeación  se reunió el 1 de septiembre, 2020. Durante esta junta Sylvia Ortega 
presentó las autoevaluaciones de Early Head Start y Head Start de Kern, durante esta 
presentación se revisaron los puntos clave con los miembros del comité. Dichas 
autoevaluaciones fuero n aprobadas por el comité.  También  se revisaron los reportes de 
inscripción de  todos los subsidios; así como el programa de cuidado alimenticio infantil y para 
adultos CACFP. Se denotó que los estándares de desempeño se han llevado a cabo 
exitosamente dur ante la pandemia de COVID -19. Por último,  se informó que las evaluaciones 
continuarán  conduciéndose mediante monitoreo , hecho que minimiza el riesgo de transmisión 
a los alumnos y empleados.    
c. Comité  de presupuestos y finanzas   
El comité  de presupuestos y finanzas se reunió  el 15 de septiembre, 2020 promedio d e 
teleconferencia.  Se revisó la  información financiera actual vs los presupuestos de todos los 
subsidios; así como también  los fondos para actividades para pad res y los reembolsos p ara 
viajes locales. El  subcomité  se reunirá nuevamente para su junta final del término  2019 -2020, el 
20 de octubre, 2020 a las 5:30 p.m. por teleconferencia.   
d. Comité  de estatutos   
El comité  de estatutos se reunió  vía teleconferencia el 8 de septiembre. 2020. El último  borrador 
de los estatutos , que incluyeron las recomendaciones de la administración, se revisaron y 
aprobaron. Se informó que no hubo ningún cambio significante al documento. El cambio más 
notable fue la incorporación  de las teleconferencias y la votación, así como obligaciones 
adicionales que se agregaron al puesto del representante de la junta directiva. También  se 
agregaron cambios  de formato y gramática  al mismo documento. Este documento de 
estatutos  se presentará  a la junta directiva de CAPK para su aprobación en su junta de 
octubre. La próxima junta del comité de estatutos, se llevará a cabo el 8 de octubre, 2020 por 
medio de teleconferencia a las 5:30 p.m.

10. Reporte del programa de Gobernanza/Capacitación  ~ Lisa Price                                                                                                     
Lisa Price agradeció a los miembros por tomar parte de su tiempo para asistir a la reunión, 
enfatizando que el fin de este periodo está cerca. Quiso notar algunos de los artículos que se 
encuentran en el paquete de la junta. Ella pidió a los miembros revis ar la información que se 
ofreció  con respecto a la prevención y seguridad  contra incendios; esto es especialmente 
importante debido a la cantidad de incendios que están ocurriendo, algunos de estos en 
proximidad. A esto añadió la importancia de contar con  un plan de contingencia para garantizar 
la seguridad de la familia . Se compartió información con respecto a los servicios  dentales  gratuitos , 
Lisa señaló  que,  durante una reciente junta del comité de preparación escolar, se expresó 
preocupación respecto a la falta de habilidad para concertar citas puntuales para los niños (as). 
Se espera que esta clínica  móvil dental gratuita, que se ofrece para menores de 0 a 5 años, será de 
beneficio para estos. Lisa hizo una breve mención  sobre el registro de votantes, exhortando a los 
presentes a registrarse o simplemente a verificar el estado de su registro . Otro tema que se 
mencionó fue el censo; se hizo hincapié  sobre el tema y su importancia, así como la variedad de 
información que se ha distribuid o a los miembros durante los últimos meses. Se pidió a los miembros 
compartir esta información con otras personas.  Para cerrar, Lisa proporcionó  la actualización de la 
encuesta del concilio de póliza  para el periodo 2020 -2021;  dicha encuesta se estará enviándose 
electrónicamente por medio de un boletín informativo (Smore). Pidió a los miembros interesados en  
 participar nuevamente a completar la encuesta; agradeció nuevamente la p articipación a todos 
los asistentes.  
 
11. Reporte de la directora  (HS/Desarrollo Infantil Estatal)  ~ Yolanda Gonzales     
Yolanda agradeció  a los miembros por la aprobación de la remisión y objetivos de San Joaquín . 
Agregó que ha sido un año bastante inusual, circunstancias a las que no estamos acostumbrados. 
Expresó  su agradecimiento por la participación y compromiso de todos los miembros del concilio 
de póliza . Yolanda añadió que el personal continúa  implementando todos los protocolos de salud 
y seguridad para proporcionar tranquilidad y comodidad a los padres para dejar a sus hijos en los 
planteles y para que la agencia continúe  brindado servicios  de alta calidad. Yolanda exhortó  a los 
miembros a compartir su historia con otros padres, mientras que Lisa se prepara a enviar la 
encuesta.  Informó que por el momento se encuentra en San Joaquín  y compartió  que siempre es 
un placer estar allí; agregando que Gloria y su equipo administrativo continúan trabajando para 
implementar el protocolo de salud y garantizar las medidas de salud y seguridad respecto a 
COVID -19. San Joaquín  continúa con las renovaciones en algunos planteles, de igual manera que 
el condado de Kern. Se anunció que el nuevo plantel Ángela  Martínez  (localizado en Kern), se 
encuentra en las últimas  etapas para su inauguración, agregó que existen muchos compon entes 
para la obtención de la licencia. Una vez más, Yolanda agradeció  a los miembros por su 
participación y apoyo por  permitirnos continuar brindado un excelente programa. Se aconsejó a 
todos a continuar a salvo; para finalizar Yolanda expresó su certidum bre sobre el retorno de 
algunos de los miembros  para el siguiente periodo, ya sea su segundo o tercer año, dijo que se 
sentirán felices de continuar proporcionando su apoyo al concilio y a nuestro programa.    
            
12. Avisos de la presidenta del Concilio de Póliza ~ Nila Hogan    
Nila Hogan  expres ó su aprecio al personal por todo lo que hacen, agregó que sabe que los padres 
verdaderamente los aprecian  y le gusta reiterar ese agradecimiento. Añadió que también  aprecia 
la participación a los miembros del concilio, pese a las presentes circunstancias. Nila reiteró 
nuevamente su gratitud a los presentes  por haber asistido a la junta de esta noche .

MEMORANDUM  
 
To:   Policy Council     
From :   Yolanda Gonzales , Director of Head Start/State Child Development   
Date :   October 2 7th, 2020    
Subject:   Early Head Start  – Child Care Partnerships  Application for Continued Funding of 
Early Head Start  Child Care Partnerships – Action Item  
 
The Office of Head Start (OHS) requires the submission of a re -funding application for the 
Early Head Start Child Care Partnerships grant #09HP000163. The application  is due 
December 1, 2020. Head Start/State Child Development is requesting approval to submit an 
application that will describe the program design, goals and objectives, approach to delivery, 
and the budget.  
 
The intent of the program is to continue our part nerships with local contractors and support a 
comprehensive service delivery plan. Our local contractors include Bakersfield College, 
Blanton CDC, Garden Pathways, Taft College, and Escuelita Hernandez. We expect to reach 
the total funded enrollment, 152 c hildren, during the new fiscal year. The program is funded 
by the C DE, OHS, and USDA.  
 
The funding levels for the 12 -month period 03/01/2021 through 02/28/2022 are:  
• $2,398,407 for program operations and $56,185 for training and technical assistance  
 
CAPK will manage the development, implementation, and evaluation of the Head Start 
Approach to School Readiness through the application of early learning theories and practices 
that are researched -based.  Non-federal share details noted within t he budget indicate the 
program costs supported by CAPK. This program supports state and county efforts to improve 
communities by promoting educational opportunities that enrich the lives of children and their 
families. Services for this funding period will  begin on March 1,2021 and will continue through 
February 28th, 2022.  
 
Attached to this action item is the budget detail of our refunding application.  
 
Recommendation  
Staff recommends the Policy Council  approve s the submission of the application for continued 
funding of  EHS CCP #09HP000163 for the 2021 -2022 budget period.

Policy Council School Readiness Subcommittee  
Meeting Minutes  
September  15, 2020 
Call In: (213) 204 -2374 Meeting ID: 721 600 319#  
 
 
1. Welcome  
The group was welcomed to the meeting.  
 
2. Call to Order  
a. Meeting was officially called to order at  5:42 p.m.  by Subcommittee 
Chairperson  Kaylonie Howard . 
 
3. Roll Call and establish Quorum (half plus one)  
a. Quorum was established . 
b. PC Members present : Kaylonie Howard, Bianca Garibay, Ana Vega, and  
Brittany Dunbar.  
c. PC Members not present:  Helena Conolly  
      
4.  Approval of Agenda  
     Motion was made by Bianca Garibay to approve the September 15, 2020 agenda,                   
           seconded by An a Vega.  Motion approved unanimously.  
 
5.  Approval of Minutes  
Motion was made by Bianca Garibay to approve the minutes dated February 18, 2020,  
seconded by Ana Vega.  Motion approved unanimously.        
            
6.  Introduction of Guests  
Guest in attendance tonight w ere Alan Rodriguez , Nicole Nino, Lisa Price.  
 
7.  Public Forum  
(The public wishing to address the PC School Readiness  Committee may do so at this 
time; however, the Committee will take no action other than referring the item to staff for 
study and analysis.)  
None  
 
8. Presentation / Discussion  Items  
a.  Alan presented the CAPK Health Protocol -Site Plan with to the School Readiness 
Subcommittee. He highlighted key areas of interest and discussed them with the 
members. Alan recapped  that the Health Protocol -Site Plan was created to ensure 
every child and staff member were in the safest environment possible due to the  
COVID -19 pandemic. He asked if anyone was currently attending a physical 
classroom and a member confirmed that the Protocol reflected what was 
happening at her childcare  site.  
 
b. Alan discussed California  Child Care Licensing requirements  for Health with t he 
committee and described how the requirements  were still in place for the children 
who are learning virtually. The requirements  discussed were Physicals, TB tests/risk 
factors, and immunizations. Alan explained  why those requirements  were put in  
 pace and  how important they are to ensure each child is healthy enough to be in 
a classroom  setting . 
 
c. Alan presented the Head Start Performance standards that  require programs to 
capture  hearing, vision , blood pressure, height and weights, and hemoglobin 
exam s/scr eenings . He described how the office of Head Start was flexible with 
these timelines,  but he also described why these requirements  were important as it 
reflected the children’s  health. CAPK Head Start purchased tolls that made the 
screening easier to condu ct internally but cannot be used at the moment due to 
COVID -19 thus the screening will have to be taken off of the children’s physicals.  
 
d. Alan Described how the mealtime  process is now  different in the classrooms due to 
COVID -19. He encouraged families to continue family style  meals  in the home so 
children can continue to gain that experience and building their skills . 
 
e. Alan shared the weekly SMORE resource that is created by support services staff for 
family members to access and use to interact with their children. He spoke about 
some of the activities that are included and encouraged the committee members 
to talk to their sites to ensure the resource is shared with them.  
 
9. Communications  
None  
 
10.  Announcements  
Alan Rodriguez announced that the Angela Martinez  Child Development Center was 
close to begin providing services. He also stated that the next meeting would be held on 
Tuesday October 20 , 2020 . Lisa Price announced the next Policy Council meeting was 
Tuesd ay September 22 , 2020 . Lisa also announced and wanted to celebrate a 
committee’s member , Ana Vega’s  upcoming birthday.  
 
11. Adjournment  
Meeting was adjourned at 6:3 2 p.m.  
 
Alan Rodriguez, Health and Nutrition Support Services Supervisor  
Completed  (9/17/2020 )

8. Presentación / Temas a tratar   
a. Alan presentó al comité de preparación escolar . El tema de su presentación se enfocó  
el protocolo de salud para las instalaciones de CAPK. Explic ó algunas de las áreas de 
interés a los miembros del comité.  Agregó  que el protocolo se creó  para garantizar la 
seguridad de los alumnos y empleados en los planteles, debido a la pandemia de 
COVID -19. Pregunt ó a los presentes si alguno de sus hijos( as) estaba  asistiendo a clases . 
Uno de los miembros confirmó la asistencia , añadiendo que los pasos  del protocolo se 
estaban siguiendo al pie de la letra en el plantel al que el alumno asistía .  
   
b. Alan  habló sobre los requisitos  de salud, instituidos por el departamento de emisión de 
licencias del estado de California, aun para aquellos alumnos que est án tomando 
clases de manera virtual. Los requisitos continúan siendo los mismos ; exigen  un examen   
 
 físico  y pruebas de factores de riesgo de tuberculosis  y vacunas.  Alan explicó los 
motivos por los cuales antedichos requisitos se establecieron y recalcó su importancia, 
ya que estos aseguran que los alumnos se encuentren en buen estado de salud para 
asistir al salón de clases.  
 
c. Alan presentó los requisitos  para los estándares de rendimiento de Head Start, los 
cuales incluyen verificación  de audición, visión  así como hemoglobina. Describió  que 
la oficina de Head  Start, era muy flexible con los plazos para estos requisitos, pero hizo 
hincapié en la importanci a que estos requisitos, ya que estos representan   
la salud de los alumnos.  También  informó a los miembros que CAPK había adquirido 
equipos de peaje . Estos facilitarán el proceso de evaluación, pe ro por el momento no 
se utilizarán  debido  a la pandemia COVID -19, se reiniciará el uso de estos aparatos a 
futuro.  
 
d. Alan también  explicó los nuevos reglamentos sobre la  distribución de alimentos en los 
salones debido a la pandemia COVID -19. Exhortó a las famil ias a continuar 
fomentando el há bito de alimentación en familia, para que los niños  continúen 
adquiriendo dicha experiencia y enriqueciendo sus habilidades.

a. 2020  Head Start & Early Head Start Kern , Goals and Objectives  ~ Jerry Meade; 
Assistant Head Start Director  
Mr. Meade review ed the HS & EHS  goals and  objectives for  Kern.  Goal I, Consistency 
of Process/Systems , is to streamline program delivery and management  systems to 
fully embrace technology and data collection processes. As noted in the progress 
notes for  Objective  B, there ha ve been many delays  due to COVID -19. The 
pandemic has resulted in delays  in the election and  implementation of a system to 
utilize  in our pilot program. The program will continue to develop policies and 
procedures with a data driven framework  and hopes to implement the pilot  in the 
next calendar  year. In Goal II , Program Infrastructure, there ha ve not been  
challenges . Progress reported states that there has been a modification in the data 
for the Health and Safety screening tool at our sites and we have established a work 
order system .  The compliance team has bee n monitoring the documentation of the 
facility renovation and this process has been working effectively . Therefore,  the 
progress of that objective will be marked as completed by the end of the program 
year. Goal III, Employee Competency and Behaviors  is to strategically align 
workforce development to build a proficient team with succession  planning that promotes longevity. In the Goal IV , the program has introduce d the Hatch Ignite 
program, which will support home base as well as center programs. Overall , there 
has been progress in the school readiness goal  though  there has been some 
challenges  with connectivity.  The goals  are a component of the application that 
will be submitted  for funding  the Head Start and Early  Head Start Kern grant . The 
application wi ll also be presented to the full Policy Council later this month for 
approval. Staff recommends the approval of the 2020 Head Start & Early Head Start 
Kern Goals and Objectives. Nicole Cabe presented a motion to approve  and Nila 
Hogan, seconded. Motion app rove d unanimously.  
b. 2020 Early Head Start Child Care Partnership , Goals and Objectives  ~ Jerry Meade; 
Assistant  Head Director.

goals for this grant as the same as those noted above for the HS and EHS Kern grant.

Competency and Behavior , and  School Readiness . The progress notes for Goal I  
indicates that this program has also faced challenges due the COVID -19 pandemic 
which has delayed the progress. In Goal II, Program Infrastructure , the efforts  to 
implement the Health and Safety Screening tool were underway before the COVID -
19 pandemic  started . Efforts  will resume in the fall of 2020. For Goal I II, Employee 
competency and Behaviors, no challenges were recorded. The program has been 
able to maintain  the community collaborative  and provi de additional training 
through  a virtual environment . For Goal IV, School Readiness, some challenges have

approval of the 2020 Early Head Start Child Care Par tnership Goals and Objectives.

El Sr. Meade reviso las metas y objetivos de Head Start y Early Head Start. El objetivo 
I: Consistencia de procesos y sistemas consiste  en optimizar la entrega de 
programas y el manejo de sistemas para incorporar completamente la tecnología y 
el proceso de recopi lación de datos. Como se señala en las notas de progreso 
para el objetivo B, ha habido un sinnúmero de retrasos debido a la pandemia de 
COVID -19. Esta pandemia ha retrasado la elección e implementación de un 
sistema para nuestro programa piloto. El program a continuará  desarrollando pólizas  
y procedimientos dentro de un marco basado en datos, y espera i mplementar el 
programa piloto el próximo año. En el objetivo II: Infraestructura  del programa, n o 
se ha  encontrado ninguna complicación. Las notas del progres o, indican que ha 
habido una modificación  en los datos de la herramienta de evaluación de Salud y 
Seguridad en los planteles y se ha establecido un sistema de solicitud de servicios. El 
equipo de consenso  ha estado monitoreando  la documentación  de renovaci ones de las instalaciones , y este proceso ha funcionado de manera efectiva. Por lo 
tanto,  el progreso de este objetivo ser marcará como  completo, al fin del ciclo 
escolar. La meta III: Competencia y Conducta  de los empleados, consiste en la 
alineación estr atégica del desarrollo de la fuerza laboral, para constituir  un equipo 
competente teniendo  como  objetivo la planificación de la sucesión que promueva 
la longevidad. En la meta IV el programa ha introducido  el programa Hatch Ignite, 
dicho programa apoyará t anto a los servicios a domicilio como a los programas en 
las guarderías. En general hemos experimentado avances en la meta de 
preparación escolar, aunque nos hemos enfrentado a algunos desafíos con la 
conectividad. Las metas son un componente de la solicitud  que se presentará para 
el financiamiento  de los programas de Head Start y Early Head Start de Kern. Dicha 
solicitud se presentar á al pleno del concilio de póliza  para su aprobación; en la 
junta a llevarse a cabo a finales del mes en curso.  El pe rsonal recomienda  la 
aprobación de las metas y objetivos de Head Start Y Early Head Start de Kern 2020. 
Nicole Cabe presentó una propuesta  para su aprobación, Nila Hogan la secundó. 
Propuesta aprobada por unanimidad.  
b. Metas y objetivos 2020 de la Asociació n de cuidado infantil Early Head ~ Jerry

 Hola soy Pip!  Flu Information
The Flu:  
A Guide for Parents 
Influenza (also known as flu) is a contagious respiratory 
illness caused by influenza viruses that infect the nose, throat 
and lungs. Flu is different from a cold, and usually comes on suddenly. Each year flu viruses cause millions of illnesses, hundreds of thousands of hospital stays and thousands or tens of thousands of deaths in the United States. 
Flu can be very dangerous for children. CDC estimates that between 6,000 and 26,000 children younger than 5 years have been hospitalized each year in the United States because of influenza. The flu vaccine is safe and helps protect children from flu.
What parents should know
How serious is flu? 
While flu illness can vary from mild to severe, children often need medical care because of flu. Children younger than 5 years and children of any age with certain long-term health problems are at high risk of flu complications like pneumonia, bronchitis, sinus and ear infections. Some health problems that are known to make children more vulnerable to flu include asthma, diabetes and disorders  
of the brain or nervous system. 
How does flu spread?
Flu viruses are thought to spread mainly by droplets made when someone with flu coughs, sneezes or talks. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people nearby. A person also can get flu by touching something that has flu virus on it and then touching their mouth, eyes, or nose.
What are flu symptoms? 
Flu symptoms can include fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, feeling tired and sometimes vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children than adults). Some people with the flu will not have a fever.Protect your child
How can I protect my child from flu?
The first and best way to protect against flu is to get a yearly flu vaccine for yourself and your child. 
 §Flu vaccination is recommended for everyone 6 months and older every year. Flu shots and nasal spray flu vaccines are both options for vaccination.
 §It’s especially important that young children and children with certain long-term health problems get vaccinated. 
 §Caregivers of children at high risk of flu complications should get a flu vaccine. (
Babies younger than 6 months  
are at high risk for serious flu complications, but too young to get a flu vaccine.)
 §Pregnant women should get a flu vaccine to protect themselves and their baby from flu. Research shows that flu vaccination protects the baby from flu for several months after birth. 
 §Flu viruses are constantly changing and so flu vaccines are updated often to protect against the flu viruses that research indicates are most likely to cause illness during the upcoming flu season. 
Is flu vaccine safe?
Flu vaccines are made using strict safety and production measures. Millions of people have safely received flu vaccines for decades. Flu shots and nasal spray flu vaccines are both options for vaccination. Different types of flu vaccines are licensed for different ages. Each person should get one that is appropriate for their age. CDC and the American Academy of Pediatrics recommend an annual flu vaccine for all children 6 months and older.
What are the benefits of getting a flu vaccine?
 §A flu vaccine can keep you and your child from getting sick. 
When vaccine viruses and circulating viruses are 
matched, flu vaccination has been shown to reduce the risk of getting sick with flu by about half.
 §Flu vaccines can keep your child from being hospitalized from flu. One recent study showed that flu vaccine reduced children’s risk of flu-related pediatric intensive care unit admission by 74%.
 §Flu vaccine can prevent your child from dying from flu.   
A study using data from recent flu seasons found that  
flu vaccine reduced the risk of flu-associated death by 
half among children with high risk medical conditions 
and by nearly two-thirds among children without medical 
conditions.
 §Flu vaccination also may make your illness milder if you 
do get sick.
 §Getting yourself and your child vaccinated also can 
protect others  who may be more vulnerable to serious  
flu illness, like babies and young children, older people, 
and people with certain long-term health problems.
What are some other ways I can protect my 
child against flu? 
In addition to getting a flu vaccine, you and your child 
should take everyday actions to help prevent the spread  
of germs.
Stay away from people who are sick as much as possible to 
keep from getting sick yourself. If you or your child are sick, 
avoid others as much as possible to keep from infecting 
them. Also, remember to regularly cover your coughs 
and sneezes, wash your hands often, avoid touching your 
eyes, nose and mouth, and clean surfaces that may be 
contaminated with flu viruses. These everyday actions can 
help reduce your chances of getting sick and prevent the 
spread of germs to others if you are sick. However, a yearly 
flu vaccine is the best way to prevent flu illness.
If your child is sick
What can I do if my child gets sick? 
Talk to your doctor early if you are worried about your 
child’s illness.  
Make sure your child gets plenty of rest and drinks  
enough fluids.
If your child is 5 years or older and does not have a long-
term health problems and gets flu symptoms, including a 
fever and/or cough, consult your doctor as needed. 
Children younger than 5 years of age – especially those 
younger than 2 years – and children with certain long-term 
health problems (including asthma, diabetes and disorders 
of the brain or nervous system), are at high risk of serious 
flu complications. Call your doctor or take your child to the 
doctor right away if they develop flu symptoms. 
What if my child seems very sick? 
Even healthy children can get very sick from flu. If your child 
is experiencing the following emergency warning signs, you 
should go to the emergency room:
 §Fast breathing or trouble breathing 
 §Bluish lips or face  §Ribs pulling in with  
each breath
 §Chest pain
 §Severe muscle pain (child 
refuses to walk)
 §Dehydration (no urine for 
8 hours, dry mouth, no 
tears when crying)
 §Not alert or interacting 
when awake
 §Seizures
 §Fever above 104°F
 §In children less than 12 
weeks, any fever
 §Fever or cough that improve but then return or worsen
 §Worsening of chronic medical conditions
This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical 
provider for any other symptom that is severe or concerning.
Is there a medicine to treat flu? 
Yes. Antiviral drugs are prescription medicines that can be 
used to treat flu illness. They can shorten your illness and 
make it milder, and they can prevent serious complications 
that could result in a hospital stay. Antivirals work best when 
started during the first 2 days of illness. Antiviral drugs are 
recommended to treat flu in people who are very sick (for 
example, people who are in the hospital) or people who are 
at high risk of serious flu complications who get flu symptoms. 
Antivirals can be given to children and pregnant women. 
How long can a sick person spread flu to others?
People with flu may be able to infect others from 1 day before 
getting sick to up to 5 to 7 days after. Severely ill people or 
young children may be able to spread the flu longer, especially if 
they still have symptoms. 
Can my child go to school, day care, or camp if 
he or she is sick? 
No. Your child should stay home to rest and to avoid spreading 
flu to other children or caregivers. 
When can my child go back to school after 
having flu? 
Keep your child home from school, day care, or camp for at 
least 24 hours after their fever is gone. (The fever should be 
gone without the use of a fever-reducing medicine.) A fever  
is defined as 100°F (37.8°C)* or higher.
*Many authorities use either 100 (37.8 degrees Celsius) or 100.4 F (38.0 degrees Celsius)  
 as a cut-off for fever, but this number can vary depending on factors such as the method  
 of measurement and the age of the person. 
For more information, visit www.cdc.gov/flu/protect/children.htm  or call 800-CDC-INFOMarch 2019 | 19_303750-A
Información sobre la influenza
La influenza:   
Guía para padres
¿Qué es la influenza? 
La influenza (también conocida como gripe) es una enfermedad 
respiratoria contagiosa causada por los virus de la influenza, que 
infectan la nariz, la garganta y los pulmones. La influenza es diferente 
a un resfriado y generalmente se presenta de manera repentina. Cada año, los virus de la influenza hacen que millones de personas se 
enfermen y cientos de miles sean hospitalizadas, y causan miles — o 
decenas de miles — de muertes en los Estados Unidos.
La influenza puede ser muy peligrosa para los niños. Los CDC estiman 
que cada año la influenza causa la hospitalización de entre 6000 
y 26 000 niños menores de 5 años por la influenza cada año en los Estados Unidos. La vacuna contra la influenza es segura y ayuda a 
proteger a los niños contra la enfermedad.
Lo que deben saber los padres
¿Qué tan grave es la influenza? 
Aunque la enfermedad de la influenza puede variar entre leve y grave, es 
frecuente que los niños necesiten atención médica. Los niños menores 
de 5 años y los de cualquier edad con ciertos problemas de salud 
de largo plazo tienen alto riesgo de presentar complicaciones por la influenza como neumonía, bronquitis e infecciones de oído o sinusitis. 
Algunos de los problemas de salud que se sabe que hacen que los 
niños sean más vulnerables a la influenza incluyen el asma, la diabetes y los trastornos del cerebro o del sistema nervioso. 
¿Cómo se propaga la influenza?
Se cree que los virus de la influenza se propagan principalmente a través de las gotitas que se forman cuando una persona con la enfermedad 
tose, estornuda o habla. Estas gotitas pueden llegar a la boca o la nariz 
de las personas que estén cerca. Una persona también puede contraer la influenza al tocar algo que tenga el virus y luego 
tocarse los ojos, la nariz o la boca.
¿Cuáles son los síntomas de la 
influenza? 
Los síntomas de la influenza pueden incluir 
fiebre, tos, dolor de garganta, moqueo o 
congestión nasal, dolores en el cuerpo, dolor 
de cabeza, escalofríos, cansancio y, en algunos casos, vómitos y diarrea (más frecuentes en los 
niños que en los adultos). Algunas personas con 
influenza no presentan fiebre.
Proteja a su hijo
¿Cómo puedo proteger a mi hijo de la influenza?
La primera y mejor manera de protegerse contra la influenza es ponerse la vacuna anual contra la influenza y ponérsela a su hijo.  
 §La vacunación contra la influenza se recomienda para todas las personas de 6 meses en adelante todos los años. Tanto la vacuna 
inyectable como la vacuna en atomizador nasal existen como opción 
para la vacunación contra la influenza.
 §Es particularmente importante que se vacunen los niños pequeños y los que tengan ciertos problemas de salud de largo plazo. 
 §También se deben vacunar las personas que cuiden a niños que estén en alto riesgo de presentar complicaciones por esta enfermedad. 
(Los bebés con menos de 6 meses de edad tienen un alto riesgo de 
presentar complicaciones graves, pero son demasiado pequeños para ser vacunados contra la influenza). 
 §Las mujeres embarazadas también deben vacunarse para protegerse y proteger al bebé. Las investigaciones han mostrado que la vacunación 
contra la influenza protege al bebé durante varios meses después de 
que nace.
Los virus de la influenza cambian constantemente, por lo tanto, las 
vacunas son actualizadas para que protejan contra los virus que, según 
indiquen las investigaciones, tengan mayores probabilidades de causar  
la enfermedad durante la siguiente temporada de influenza.
¿Son seguras las vacunas contra la influenza?
Las vacunas contra la influenza se hacen usando estrictas medidas de seguridad y producción. Millones de personas las han recibido de manera 
segura durante décadas. Tanto la vacuna inyectable como la vacuna en 
atomizador nasal son opciones de vacunación contra la influenza. Hay distintos tipos de vacuna contra la influenza aprobados para personas 
de diferentes edades. Cada persona debe ponerse la vacuna que sea 
adecuada para su edad. Los CDC y la Academia Estadounidense de Pediatría recomiendan que todos los niños de 6 meses de edad en 
adelante reciban una vacuna anual contra la influenza.
¿Cuáles son los beneficios de recibir una vacuna 
contra la influenza?
 §La vacunación contra la influenza puede prevenir que usted y 
su hijo se enfermen. Cuando los virus de la vacuna coinciden con 
los que están circulando, la vacunación ha mostrado reducir en aproximadamente la mitad el riesgo de enfermarse.
 §Las vacunas contra la influenza pueden prevenir que su hijo sea 
hospitalizado por esta enfermedad. Un estudio reciente mostró que 
la vacunación redujo en un 74 % el riesgo de hospitalizaciones de niños en la unidad de cuidados intensivos pediátricos relacionadas  
con la influenza.
 §La vacunación contra la influenza puede prevenir que su hijo muera por esta enfermedad.  En un estudio en el que se usaron los datos 
de temporadas de influenza recientes se halló que en los niños con afecciones de alto riesgo la vacuna redujo en la mitad el riesgo de muerte asociada a la influenza y que en aquellos sin afecciones lo 
redujo en casi dos tercios. 
 §En caso de contraer la influenza, la vacunación también puede hacer 
que la enfermedad sea más leve. 
 §Si usted y su hijo se vacunan, también pueden proteger a otras personas  que quizás sean más vulnerables a enfermarse gravemente, 
como los bebés y niños pequeños, las personas mayores y las personas que tengan ciertos problemas de salud de largo plazo. 
¿De qué otras maneras puedo proteger a mi hijo 
contra la influenza? 
Además de ponerse una vacuna contra la influenza, usted y su hijo 
deben tomar medidas diarias para ayudar a prevenir la propagación  
de los microbios. 
Dentro de lo posible, manténganse alejados de las personas que estén 
enfermas para evitar enfermarse. Si usted o su hijo están enfermos, 
eviten estar con otras personas lo más posible para no contagiarlas. 
Además, recuerden cubrirse la nariz y la boca cuando tosan o estornuden, lavarse las manos frecuentemente, limpiar las superficies que puedan 
estar contaminadas con virus de la influenza y evitar tocarse los ojos, la 
nariz y la boca. Estas medidas cotidianas pueden ayudar a reducir sus probabilidades de enfermarse y prevenir la propagación de microbios a 
otras personas, si se enferman. Sin embargo, la vacunación anual contra 
la influenza es la mejor forma de prevenir esta enfermedad. 
Si su hijo está enfermo 
¿Qué puedo hacer si mi hijo se enferma?  
Hable con el médico pronto si le preocupa la enfermedad de su hijo.  
Asegúrese de que descanse mucho y tome suficientes líquidos. 
Si su hijo tiene 5 años o más y no tiene problemas de salud de largo plazo, 
pero presenta síntomas de influenza (como fiebre o tos) consulte con  
su médico según sea necesario. 
Los niños menores de 5 — especialmente los que tienen menos de 2 
años — y los que tienen ciertos problemas de salud de largo plazo (como asma, diabetes, o trastornos del cerebro o del sistema nervioso) están 
en alto riesgo de presentar complicaciones graves relacionadas con la 
influenza. Llame o lleve a su hijo al médico de inmediato si el niño tiene síntomas de influenza.  
¿Qué debo hacer si mi hijo parece estar muy 
enfermo? 
Incluso los niños sanos pueden enfermarse gravemente por la 
influenza. Si su hijo tiene alguna de las siguientes señales de 
advertencia que indiquen que se trata de una emergencia debe 
llevarlo a la sala de emergencias:
 §Respiración rápida o dificultad para respirar.
 §Coloración azulada en los labios o la cara.
 §Opresión en las costillas con cada respiración.
 §Dolor en el pecho.
 §Dolor muscular grave (el niño se niega a caminar).
 §Deshidratación (no orinar por 8 horas, tener la boca seca, llorar  
sin lágrimas).
 §No está alerta ni interactúa cuando está despierto. 
 §Convulsiones.
 §Fiebre superior a 104 °F (40 oC).
 §En los niños menores de 12 semanas, toda fiebre.
 §Fiebre o tos que mejoran, pero luego vuelven o empeoran. §Empeoramiento de afecciones crónicas.
Esta lista no incluye todas las señales de 
advertencia. Consulte con su proveedor 
de atención médica si tiene cualquier otro síntoma grave o que le preocupe.
¿Hay algún medicamento 
para tratar la influenza?  
Sí. Los antivirales son 
medicamentos recetados que 
se pueden usar para tratar la 
influenza. Pueden reducir la duración de la enfermedad y 
hacerla más leve. También pueden 
prevenir las complicaciones graves que podrían llevar a una hospitalización. Los 
medicamentos antivirales son más 
eficaces si se comienza a tomarlos en los primeros 2 días de la enfermedad. 
Los medicamentos antivirales se 
recomiendan para tratar la influenza en las personas muy enfermas (por ejemplo, las personas que están en el hospital) o que tengan alto riesgo de 
presentar complicaciones graves. Los medicamentos antivirales pueden 
darse a los niños y a las mujeres embarazadas. 
¿Por cuánto tiempo puede una persona enferma 
transmitir la influenza a otras personas?
Las personas que tengan influenza pueden infectar a los demás desde 1 día 
antes de enfermarse hasta 5 a 7 días después. Las personas que estén muy 
enfermas y los niños pequeños podrían transmitirla durante más tiempo, 
especialmente si todavía tienen síntomas.
¿Mi hijo puede ir a la escuela, la guardería o el 
campamento si está enfermo? 
No. Su hijo debe quedarse en casa para descansar y evitar contagiarles la 
influenza a los otros niños y a las personas que lo cuiden. 
¿Cuándo puede regresar mi hijo a la escuela 
después de haber tenido la influenza?  
Mantenga a su hijo en casa y espere al menos 24 horas después de que ya 
no tenga fiebre para llevarlo a la escuela, la guardería o el campamento. 
(La fiebre debe haber desaparecido sola, sin el uso de medicamentos que 
reduzcan la fiebre). La fiebre se define como una temperatura de 100 °F (37.8 °C) o mayor.
*Muchas autoridades usan los 100 o 100.4 oF (37.8 o 38 oC) como temperatura de corte  
 de fiebr e, pero este número puede variar dependiendo de factores como el método  
 que se  use para medir la fiebre y la edad de la persona.
Para obtener más información, visite  
espanol.cdc.gov/enes/flu  
o llame al 800-CDC-INFOApril 2019 | 19_304207-A

What Is Domestic Violence?What Is Domestic Violence?
Domestic violence is a pattern of coercive behavior that one partner in a romantic or intimate 
relationship uses to gain and maintain power and control over another partner. It is not an isolated, individual event. Domestic violence can involve several tactics such as physical, emotional, sexual, and financial abuse. 
Domestic violence can happen to anyone of any age, race, sexual orientation, gender identity, 
gender, religion, educational level, or socioeconomic background, regardless of whether couples are married, living together, dating, or hooking up.  
Relationships where one partner is using violence to control another partner can also involve 
stalking, sexual assault, and rape.
Who Is Affected by Domestic Violence? 
• More than one-third of women in the United States have experienced rape, physical violence, 
and/or stalking by an intimate partner at some point in their lifetime.
• Approximately one in seven men have experienced severe physical violence from an intimate partner during their lifetime.
• One in five children is exposed to family violence in their lifetime. This exposure includes witnessing violence against a parent or sibling. By age 17, approximately one-third of youth in the United States have witnessed family violence.
• Children of either partner may be direct victims of abuse or suffer from exposure to the violence.
(Black et al., 2011)
How Does Domestic Violence Affect Children and Families? 
It is important to remember that domestic violence may impact every individual and family 
differently. Research shows that all young children who experience domestic violence are affected. Children may experience different effects depending on exposure and genetic and environmental buffers. It is important, therefore, to partner with parent and child survivors to tailor your support.
The response that young children have to the experience of domestic violence depends on a 
number of factors, including age, severity of the violence, gender, temperament, and access to protective factors. Head Start and Early Head Start programs can use this resource to learn  what domestic violence is, how it affects children and families, and where to  find resources for children and families experiencing domestic violence.  Page  2
What Is Domestic Violence?Domestic violence can affect children’s ability to learn and grow. It can lead to developmental 
delays, an inability to manage emotions, impaired ability to focus, and trouble learning (The National Child Traumatic Stress Network, n.d.). 
Children who experience prolonged exposure 
to abuse and violence also may experience significant prolonged developmental and/or behavioral issues. These children may have health issues as adolescents and adults. These issues may include heart disease, stroke, depression, suicide attempts, sexually transmitted diseases, and substance abuse.
A person’s identity—race, ethnicity, age, sexual 
orientation, gender identity, disability, and immigration or refugee status—influences how the person experiences and responds to domestic violence. Support for families should take into consideration their cultures, identities, and life experiences.
Is Healing Possible for Children and Families?
Relationships with supportive adults are key to 
helping children who have experienced domestic violence heal and thrive. 
Children’s ability to do well or develop resilience often emerges from a combination of factors. 
These include biological resistance to adversity and strong relationships with the adults in their lives—parents, other family members, teachers, coaches, and health care providers. Use the following resources to learn more about supporting resilience.
Protective factors are conditions or attributes of individuals, families, communities, or the 
larger society that mitigate or eliminate risk and promote well-being. The presence of strong protective factors in families increases the probability of achieving positive outcomes, even in the face of adversity.Young children (from birth to age 5) who 
witness or experience domestic violence may also experience:
• 
Generalized anxiety
• Trouble sleeping or nightmares
• Inability to sit still or hyperactivity
• Increased aggression or withdrawal
• Increased separation anxiety and 
worries about their parent’s safety
• Increased startle response and increased fussiness
• Trouble nursing or eating
• Loss of acquired skills
• Disrupted attachment relationship with their parent
(The National Child Traumatic Stress 
Network, n.d.)Page  3

Does a grown-up always pay attention to things that are cooking?
Does a grown-up watch the stovetop when he or she is frying, boiling, grilling, or broiling food? If a grown-up must leave the kitchen for even a short period of time, does he or she turns oﬀ the burner?
Are things that can burn, such as dish towels, curtains, or paper, away from the stovetop?
Are the stovetop, burners, and oven clean — no spilled food, grease, paper or bags?Are pot handles turned toward the back of the stove when a grown-up is cooking?
Do children and pets stay out of the kid-free zone
 (3 feet or 1 meter from the stove)  when a grown-up is cooking?
Are containers opened slowly when removing from the microwave? Hot steam can escape from containers
and cause burns.
Does your family have working smoke alarms on every level of the home, outside all sleeping areas,
and in each bedroom?
Does your family have a home ﬁre escape plan?

HEAD START GRADUATE, 1968
In 2018, onlyIn 1967, my mother enrolled me in Head Start at 3 years
old. I loved the environment, the teachers, socialization
and field trips! After that first year ended, I was more
social, and began putting letters together to spell
words. I started reading simple books at 4 years of age.
My love for learning began in Head Start. Though I was
born to a teen mother, she instilled the importance of
learning and supported my school experiences at home.
Years later, I remember accompanying my grandmother
to the Head Start program in her community where she
worked as a cook. I got to help the students, reading
and playing with them. 
 
Now, I serve as the program governance coordinator at
Community Action Partnership of Kern Head Start. I
thoroughly enjoy the interactions I have with parents
and exposing them to leadership opportunities. I am
proud to be a part of a program that empowers parents
with the necessary tools for today, tomorrow and the
future of their family. Head Start matters; it is where I
started and where I will stay. Head Start is a part of me!
